texts.shortText:
Unusual calcified hydroid that grows on the surfaces of gastropod shells, both while they are still alive and when subsequently occupied by hermit crabs. The colony starts as a thin, hard, chalky-white calcareous crust, but later develops complex ridges, elongate spines and fluted processes that extend well beyond the original shell and render the host shells virtually unidentifiable.

The feeding polyps are creamy white and have 5-12 tentacles, of which one or two are typically longer than the others. The reproductive individuals bear ball-like sporosacs and male and females occur on separate colonies.
Polyps about 3 mm, colonies several cm across, completely covering host shells.

Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Orange River to Durban.

Instantly recognizable species that is common on a wide range of both living gastropod shell and shells occupies by hermits. Initially fairly smooth, but later strongly spiked and ridged and may provide additional protection to the host.
Not studied, but presumed to feed on small particles and planktonic organisms in the water surrounding the host shell, perhaps also particles released by the feeding activities of the host.

Male and female reproductive individuals (gonozooids) borne on different colonies, smaller than feeding individuals (about 0.5 mm in length), have rudimentary tentacles and bear several sporosacs. Female sporosacs each bear a single egg which develops in situ into a planula larva.

Easily identified by the calcareous skeleton, especially where this develops large external processes. Several other hydroid species also found on the surfaces of gastropod shells (for example Hydractinia altispina on the whelk Nucella squamosa), but these lack a calcareous skeleton and are usually restricted to a single gastropod host.

Day, JH (1969). A Guide to Marine Life on South African Shores. A.A. Balkema, Cape Town (p. 25).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 58).

Millard, NAH (1975). Monograph on the Hydroida of Southern Africa. Annals of the South African Museum, 68, 1-513 (p. 116).
